abstracts.cdata!:
This is the Implementation Completion
            Report (ICR) for the Seventh Education Project in Jordan.
            The objectives of the Seventh Education Project were to: (a)
            improve the quality, relevance and cost efficiency of
            education; (b) reinforce institution building; and (c)
            strengthen the linkage between education/vocational training
            and skilled manpower demand. Bank performance was
            satisfactory. Borrower performance was satisfactory. Key
            lessons of experience were : (i) the project enjoyed the
            strong ownership of the Government because it was consistent
            with Jordan's education reform program and was well
            designed; (ii) by transferring the teacher training program
            to the first sector loan the Bank showed appropriate
            flexibility in modifying the scope of the project to adapt
            to new developments without diluting a major objective;
            (iii) studies, in this case the community college study,
            need to be carefully timed and synchronized with other work
            being carried out by the Borrower; (iv) the processing
            timetable for donor cofinancing for technical assistance and
            subsequent development of terms of reference and contracting
            arrangements should be determined in advance and monitored
            to ensure the best results; and (v) the abrupt dissolution
            of a well functioning and well staffed project
            implementation unit which is familiar with Bank
            implementation procedures can disrupt project implementation
            and result in the non-use of, in this case, a small amount
            of loan funds on which the government has paid commitment
            fees and interest charges.

abstracts.cdata!:
The Seventh Education Project aims to
            assist the Government of Jordan to further develop and
            implement its medium-term education and training strategy.
            The project intends to focus on improving the quality,
            relevance and cost efficiency of education; on institution
            building; and on strengthening the linkage between
            education/vocational training and skilled manpower demand.
            To this end, the project involves improving the quality of
            basic education; improving the quality of physical
            facilities and reducing cost per student place; and
            improving responsiveness of vocational training to labor
            market needs.  In addition, this project entails
            strengthening education planning, management, and the system
            for measurement and evaluation of education quality.
